Description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ordered Santander Bank, N.A. to pay a $10 million fine for illegal overdraft service practices. The agency said Santander's telemarketing vendor deceptively marketed the overdraft service and signed certain bank customers up for the service without their consent.

Agency: Office of the Comptroller of the Currency

Description: The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency terminated mortgage servicing-related consent orders against U.S. Bank National Association and Santander Bank, N.A., and assessed civil money penalties against the banks for previous violations of the orders.
Agency: Office of the Comptroller of the Currency

Description: Santander Consumer USA Inc. agreed to pay at least $9.35 million to resolve a lawsuit by the Department of Justice alleging that the motor vehicle lender violated the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act through improper repossessions.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: Ten mortgage servicing companies subject to enforcement actions for deficient practices in mortgage loan servicing and foreclosure processing reached an agreement in principle with the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Reserve Board to pay more than $8.5 billion in cash payments and other assistance to help borrowers.
Agency: Office of the Comptroller of the Currency

Description: Santander agreed to pay $22 million in settlement of allegations it facilitated unfair high rate auto loans, with knowledge that many of the loans would default.

Santander Consumer USA Holdings, Inc. agreed to pay over $1 million to the Delaware Consumer Protection fund and $2.875 million in restitution in settlement of allegations it funded auto loans that it knew to be based on incorrect information and likely to default.
Santander agreed to pay $100,000 and reimburse clients in settlement of allegations of deceptive marketing of unsuitable variable annuity products to seniors.
Santander agreed to provide $5.4 million in debt relief in settlement of allegations it charged excessive interest rates on subprime auto loans.

Santander agreed to pay $550 million to resolve multistate litigation alleging that the bank, through its use of proprietary credit scoring models to forecast default risk, knew that certain consumer segments were likely to default, yet issued high-interest automobile loans to them anyway.

Santander Consumer USA, Inc. dba Helpingloans.com and Roadloans.com agreed to pay $300,000 in administrative penalties in settlement of allegations it failed to make certain disclosures on its loans that were required by state regulations.
Agency: California Department of Financial Protection and Innovation

Description: Santander agreed to pay $100,000 in settlement of an Administrative Order alleging it charged unlawful fees on its loans.
Santander agreed to pay $75,000 to resolve allegations that it made harassing debt collection calls.

Agency: New Hampshire Bureau of Securities Regulation
New Hampshire Bureau of Securities Regulation

Notes: Vermont was not part of a multistate settlement.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority ordered Santander Securities LLC to pay approximately $4.3 million in restitution to certain customers who were solicited to purchase Puerto Rican Municipal Bonds (PRMBs). Additionally, the firm was required to pay restitution of $121,000 and make offers of rescission to buy back the securities sold to certain customers impacted by the firm's failure to supervise employee trading. FINRA also censured and fined Santander $2 million for supervisory failures related to sales of PRMBs and Puerto Rican closed-end funds, and for failing to reasonably supervise employee trading in its Puerto Rico branch office.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined Santander Securities of Puerto Rico $2 million for deficiencies in its structured product business, including unsuitable sales of reverse convertible securities to retail customers, inadequate supervision of sales of structured products, inadequate supervision of accounts funded with loans from its affiliated bank, and other violations related to the offering and sale of structured products.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: Santander Consumer USA, Inc., a large subprime auto financing company, resolved allegations of predatory lending by agreeing to provide $3.065 million in debt relief for 340 Colorado consumers.

Santander agreed to pay $3.7 million, including $1.8 million restitution, in settlement of allegations it violated the Mississippi Consumer Protection Act by exposing consumers to high levels of  risk, placing these consumers into auto loans that had a high probability of default, and engaging in aggressive collection practices.

Company: Santander Consumer USA Inc, dba Chrysler Capital

Description: A subprime auto lender will pay $5.56 million to resolve allegations that it did not provide sufficient disclosures to consumers as it pertains to the company's auto loan debt collection practices.
